description.narrative: Output 2.3 Capacity of ministries and institutions for the collections, analysis and storage of labour market data and youth employment programming developed.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: • Number of youth (women, men, girls and boys) benefitted • Number of project board meetings held • Number of project board reports generated

comment.narrative: (1) 200 youth (at least 30% women and girls) in Baidoa and Kismayo provided with psycho-social, civic education, literacy and numeracy learning support as well as life-skills. (2) At least 2 public infrastructure (one from SWS and another from Jubaland) rehabilitated. (3) 100% delivery (4) 3 Project Board held (5) 3 project progress and monitoring report generated.

(1) 200 youth at risk (46% women) in Baidoa and Kismayo (100 from each district), being aware of the social norms and responsibilities through civic education, were trained successfully in eight market-oriented vocational and business management skills. These acquired skills in vocational areas were: beauty therapy (including Henna body-painting), tailoring, catering, auto-mechanic and driving, mobile repairing, electrical Installation, masonry, and fishing. In the initial phase of 3 months, the youth, having gone through psycho-social counselling, mentoring and gender-sensitive civic education courses, learned in youth leadership, stress management, conflicts resolution, good governance, rule of law, human rights as well as numeracy and literacy. In the 2nd phase of 5 months, the youth were trained in the market-oriented life-skills training, approved by the Ministry of Education. To enhance the possibility of employability, the trained youth were awarded with the certificates as well as received startup grants/tool kits, based on their performance and scores in their final examination - most of them secured above 80% marks. Additionally, several youth, through job placement, have already registered themselves to work with the local established enterprises to sharpen their skills further. A networking system has been created between the trained youth and the potential employers in the local markets, for providing self-employment and waged-employments to the youth. At the end of 2018, around 70 trained youth have been gainfully employed through setting up their own businesses or employed in some established companies in their local markets. The communities, including the enrolled youth, were sensitized and aware of the importance of initiative that promoted social cohesion. There is a plan in plan to scale up this initiative to Xudur district of South West State, having taken into consideration of the lessons learned and good practices.
(2) Infrastructure Rehabilitation in Baidoa and Kismayo: For rehabilitation purposes, the critical premises/ infrastructure, such as a bridge and a youth centre were selected in Baidoa; whereas a premises was selected to construct a Youth Centre in Kismayo. Accordingly, the designs and Bill of Quantity (BoQ) were developed and approved by the local authorities. The construction/rehabilitation of infrastructure are at different stages in both Baidoa and Kismayo. It is expected that the construction works will be completed by the end of March 2019. (3) Regular progress and monitoring reports developed and shared with the partners for taking necessary actions on recommendations.

a)75 youth (50% women) in Hudur/SWS, provided with psycho social counselling, training and education b) 75 youth got job placement and at least 20 of them self-employed through setting up their own businesses c) 2 public infrastructure (one from each region -Jubaland and South West) rehabilitated; and full satisfaction of the end users d) 100% delivery rate, with 1 Project Board held, 1 project Progress and 3 monitoring reports generated.

a) In Hudur district of South West State, 75 unemployed young people at risk (38 women) changed their behaviours and understandings as good citizens through a 3-month tailor-made psycho-social rehabilitation programme. b) After undergoing the psycho-social rehabilitation programme, 75 young people (38 women) learned market-oriented vocational and entrepreneurship development skills, which helped them to be empowered economically. Out of 75, 30 young people (15 women) self-employed by setting up and managing their own MSMEs. Others are in search of job opportunities. The employability of the young people improved through the provision of literacy and numeracy skills, life-skills, entrepreneurship skills, certificates, startup seed monies, tool kits and BDS services. c) One youth centre in Baidoa and an Inji Youth Centre in Kismayo were rehabilitated. The main bridge, that connects Baidoa with the rest, was rehabilitated. Hundreds of young people in Baidoa and Kismayo were using the rehabilitated youth centres. Similarly, the total population of Baidoa city were using the rehabilitated bridge. A total 138 unemployed (50 women) got short-term (3 months) employment opportunities, by following a labour intensive construction method. d) The project completed implementation of all the planned activities, prior to the end of the project, that is: 31st August 2019. A final project report was developed and shared with the partners. The delivery rate stood at 90%.
